The Executive Directors are committed to promoting and improving the quality and safety of care and treatment all patients receive, as well as preserving the safety of its staff, visitors and others. In order to achieve this, it is important to support and embed a safety culture throughout the organisation to enable learning when things go wrong.

Fear of blame may deter staff from reporting an incident or near miss event. The Executive Directors support the view that the response to incidents should not be one of blame but of organisational learning to encourage participation in the process and support staff.
In particular the Trust will:

Ensure a just culture is promoted in accordance with the NHSI Just Culture guide (Appendix A) to assure staff the Trust operates an open and honest environment where no one will be unfairly blamed when things go wrong.
Ensure effective record keeping and reporting mechanisms are in place.
Ensure that all incidents are managed in a timely and organised manner.
Ensure clear lines of accountability and responsibility are identified for all elements of incident management, including serious incidents.
Ensure that all staff, including bank, locum and agency staff, are aware of the communication systems in place for the management of all types of incidents, via appropriate induction and training.
Ensure key communication mechanisms are established with family and/or carers in line with the Trust's Being Open policy and legislative and contractual requirements of Duty of Candour.
Ensure all appropriate levels of debrief and communication of lessons learned takes place following incidents.
Ensure all relevant internal and external stakeholders, agencies and regulatory bodies are engaged, involved and informed in line with national legislation and guidelines.
Ensure lessons are learned from reported incidents, and appropriate action is taken to avoid recurrence, including making changes to practice, systems and process, and/or the environment.
Ensure no disciplinary action will result from reporting an incident (including mistakes and near misses) unless there is evidence of:
Failure to report errors or violations is a breach of Trust policy and will be considered as part of the disciplinary process.

data.text: The Chief Executive and the Executive Directors are committed to supporting patient and staff safety, and wish to make it clear to all staff throughout the organisation that it is unacceptable to prioritise other objectives at the expense of safety

The collation and analysis of data from incidents and near misses is an intrinsic part of risk management as it provides valuable opportunities to learn and improve (definitions and a glossary of terms can be found at Appendix B).
This policy describes the Mid and South Essex (MSE) NHS Foundation Trust arrangements for reporting incidents of all types and levels of significance, and
the actions expected to manage and follow-up such incidents to minimise the risk of them happening again.

The policy supports the MSE Risk Management Strategy and Procedure and must be considered in conjunction with the Procedure for the management of incidents and serious incidents and other MSE and site policies as set out at the beginning of this policy as well as legislation and national guidance described in Section 17.

Incidents and near misses that occur in the delivery of healthcare provide opportunities for investigation and improvement in systems and process to minimise the risk of recurrence. Serious Incidents (SIs) in healthcare are rare, but when they do occur, all healthcare provider organisations must make sure there are systematic measures in place to respond to them. Such measures are in order to protect patients and ensure that robust investigations are carried out, which result in learning to minimise the risk of recurrence.

All providers of health and social care in England have a statutory duty to report serious incidents to the body that commissioned the service where the incident occurred. In addition, providers have a responsibility to report certain adverse events to the appropriate regulatory body. This includes the Care Quality Commission, the Health and Safety Executive and any other regulatory or statutory body. The purpose of this policy is to provide a means of identifying and reducing the risks to which the organisation, its patients and staff, contractors, volunteers and members of the public may be exposed, and maintain the reputation of the Trust.

The Procedure for the Reporting and Management of Incidents and Serious Incidents together with the process map in Appendix E provide staff with clear guidance on how to respond to, report, manage, investigate and learn from incidents, including serious incidents (SIs).

This policy applies to all MSE staff, including volunteers and those employed on a bank, agency or locum basis. Implementation does not replace the personal responsibilities of staff with regard to issues of professional accountability.
Where staff feel unable to report errors or violations, staff should use alternative routes described within the site Speaking Up Policy.

Reporting of Injuries, Diseases and Dangerous Occurrences Regulations (RIDDOR) reportable incidents is detailed in the Health and Safety Policy. Please contact the Health and & Safety Manager who will then report the incident to the HSE should it be necessary.
Reporting criteria
The Trust recognises that for certain incidents the requirement to involve an external body in the investigation process is a statutory duty. These include:
Suicides;
Safeguarding Children and Adults at risk including child death review;
Health and Safety Executive (HSE) including RIDDOR;
Healthcare Associated Infections;
National Screening Programme;
Information Governance Commissioner;
Human Tissue Authority (HTA) related to the Post Mortem Sector License;
Healthcare Safety Investigation Branch (HSIB) - maternity incidents that meet the criteria;
Police.
4.1.1 Where the requirement to notify or involve an external body is immediate, the on-call Director must be notified, however time should not be lost in making the initial contact
Other agencies with a remit for serious incidents
Other external agencies or bodies must be notified about incidents relevant to their statutory remit and current guidelines.
Care Quality Commission;
Care Quality Commission on behalf of the Department of Health for Ionising Radiation (Medical Exposure) Regulations (IRMER) incidents;
HM Coroner;
Human Tissue Authority (HTA);
Information Commissioner;
Local Authority where safeguarding threshold met;
National Screening programmes (refer to Appendix G);
NHS England;
NHS Improvement;
Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA);
Public Health England;
Serious Hazards of Transfusion (SHOT).
4.2.1  This is not an exhaustive list and other agencies may need to be alerted depending on the nature of the incident.
Further details can be found at Appendix C.
Roles and responsibilities
Quality Governance Committee

5.1.1 Provider organisations are required to have a relevant committee/mechanism and governance in place to consider and monitor serious incident investigations. The MSE Quality Governance Committee undertakes this role on behalf of the Trust Board.

5.1.2 QGC terms of reference will include the need to ensure that regular thematic reviews are undertaken to extract learning and support the development of organisational memory and continuous improvement with regard to patient safety. In addition, the committees have responsibility for receiving appropriate assurance that adequate governance arrangements are in place to monitor the completion of action plans and the subsequent effectiveness of any risk reduction measures introduced.
Serious Incident (SI) Executive Review Group
5.2.1 The SI Executive Review Group is a working group. The function of thrice weekly meetings of this group is to:

Review all incidents identified as potential Serious Incidents following daily quality assurance review by the Patient Safety Team, as identified on the Trust's electronic Incident Reporting System. It will consider whether they meet the criteria for reporting as a serious incident, approve grading decision and STEiS submission. Details of levels of incident can be found at Appendix D).
Consider any emerging themes/concerns observed by the Patient Safety Team that do not meet the triggers described above.
Provide a clear auditable record of the regular director review of patient safety concerns and associated decisions, including the serious incident approvals process.
5.2.2 The Investigation Review Panel (IRP)

The IRP is a sub-group of the ERG. It is responsible for the review of serious incident reports and action plans with a view to recommending approval to the ERG and onward submission of approved reports to the appropriate commissioner(s).

When the evidence for closure of actions has been approved by the IRP, the action plans will be considered by the Executive Assurance group to ensure the action taken will provide sustained improvement.

Directors' Forum / Senior Management Group ensures accountability from divisions regarding the implementation of actions and dissemination of learning following serious incidents, or other incident trends highlighting emerging issues. It receives assurance that the Trust's Being Open and Duty of Candour policy is adhered to in terms of informing patients and/or relatives of
investigations into potential Serious Incidents and the subsequent sharing of reports.

Patient Safety and Quality Group (PS&QG) is responsible for the initiation and management of cross-cutting patient safety initiatives arising from serious incidents, or other themes/trends highlighting emerging issues, and provides a forum for shared learning. This includes the dissemination of patient safety alerts and any additional staff training requirements. The PS&QG may delegate specific work streams to a task and finish group if and when appropriate.

Divisional / Directorate and CSU Governance Forums are responsible for reviewing all serious incident reports, recommendations and actions, monitoring implementation of improvements and clinical specialty shared learning.
Other Committees/Groups with responsibilities for taking account of incidents:
Audit Committee;
Patient Safety and Quality Group;
Infection Prevention and Control Group;
Harm Free Care (Falls, Pressure Ulcers);
Medicines Assurance Group;
Safeguarding Groups;
Health and safety Groups;
Other task and finish/working groups authorised by the Board or its sub- committees.
Executive Group

The principal accountability of all providers of NHS-funded care is to patients and their families/carers. In their fulfilment of the Trust's duty in this regard, the Board must ensure that an appropriate incident management system is in place for the reporting of incidents and monitoring of incident trends, including serious incidents, and the recording of all Never Events in the annual reporting arrangements. Provider organisations are also accountable for effective governance and learning following a serious incident, and it is the duty of the Board to ensure appropriate arrangements are in place throughout the Trust to meet this expectation.
Role and responsibilities of individuals within the Trust

5.8.1 Chief Executive is accountable and responsible to the Board for ensuring that resources, policies and procedures are in place to ensure the effective reporting, recording, investigation and treatment of incidents.

5.8.2 Chief Nurse is the nominated Executive Director responsible for ensuring the MSE Group has appropriate arrangements in place for the management of incident reporting and associated investigation.

5.8.3 Site Director of Nursing and Site Medical Director are responsibility for managing incidents and defining and verifying an adverse event as a serious incident is delegated to the Site Director of Nursing and the Site Medical Director as part of the Director review process. Once verified, the designated site lead for Governance or his/her deputy will ensure the appropriate internal and external reporting is carried out and the investigation commences in accordance with this policy and procedure.
5.8.4 Care Group Senior Leadership Teams

All members of the Executive Group and Care Group Senior Leadership Teams are responsible for ensuring incident reporting arrangements as described in this policy are implemented throughout their service areas.
5.8.5 Designated Lead for Governance is responsible for ensuring the following systems are in place and operate effectively.
Maintaining records of reported incidents using the Trust's incident management system.
Monitoring the appropriate reporting and grading of reported incidents, and seeking clarification from relevant managers should grading be inconsistent with trends.
Ensuring appropriate notification of incidents to relevant internal and external stakeholders, agencies and regulatory bodies.

Notifying the Site and care group Leadership Teams and all other relevant stakeholders, of unexpected deaths or other serious incidents that may attract media attention, ensuring the Chief Nurse is informed.
Providing appropriate advice and support to the Care Group Leadership Teams to enable the accurate identification, reporting and investigation of serious incidents.
Liaising with the Communication Team on any incidents that may result in media interest.
Ensuring appropriate management reports from the responsible manager are completed in the event of a potential or actual serious incident.
Instigating serious incident investigations and other internal investigations/reviews in line with this policy and published best practice guidance.

Ensuring an effective quality assurance process is in place to monitor the quality of investigations, associated reports and action plans prior to submission to the designated committee or group and commissioning body.

Ensuring an effective tracking system is in place so that progress against action plans arising from serious and other grades of incident can be monitored and reported on to the appropriate committee or group.
Ensuring that evidence is collected and appropriately stored to validate the implementation of recommendations and actions arising from serious incidents.
Ensuring assurance evidence can be retrieved in a timely way when required.
Analysing incident data to produce performance, management and assurance reports including regular analysis of serious incidents to the designated committee or group.
Alerting the appropriate director, manager, consultant, specific department or governance forum if any trend(s) is identified from reported incidents.

Patient Safety Team has delegated day-to-day management responsibility for the site's electronic incident management system together with all other systems related to the recording, analysis and tracking of incidents, serious incidents and associated action plans. It also has responsibility to provide bespoke training relating to all aspects of incident reporting, investigation and management.

5.9.1 The Patient Safety Team will inform the relevant triumvirate or service leads including the link for Governance whenever a SI is reported/identified by whatever route to ensure that appropriate immediate investigation is conducted (Initial Management Review).

5.9.2 In the event of a SI being confirmed, the Patient Safety Team will request the details of an Investigating Officer (IO) who is appropriately trained and experienced to lead the serious incident investigation (see training section).

5.9.3 Following the decision to declare an incident as a serious incident the Patient Safety Team will inform the appropriate commissioning body and record the incident on the electronic Strategic Executive Information System (StEIS) within 2 working days. The Patient Safety Team will work with the Division/Directorate to ensure an updated initial management review report is submitted to the commissioning body within 3 working days, followed by a robust investigation and an approved report and action plan submitted within 60 working days from the date of reporting on StEIS.

5.9.4 The Patient Safety Team will oversee the completion and submission of reports and action plans, together with tracking completion of actions, ensuring appropriate assurance evidence is received, properly stored and available for internal or external inspection.
Communication Team will facilitate and coordinate any communications with the media in accordance with the relevant media relations policy.
Investigating Officer (IO)

5.11.1 In the event of a serious incident, internal incident or incident requiring investigation as described in section 4.1 the relevant Division will allocate an appropriately trained Investigation Officer (IO). The IO will be provided with clear terms of reference within which to conduct the investigation. In addition to the standard terms of reference set for every SI there will also be specific terms of reference.
5.11.2 The IO will undertake a Root Cause Analysis (RCA) investigation at the required level and compile a report using the Trust approved templates.

5.11.3 The IO will provide documentary evidence in support of the investigation findings and conclusions for safekeeping by the Patient Safety Team. This will include copies of evidence, statements and completed analysis tools. Following approval of the report at the Executive Review Group (ERG) the findings will be fed back as identified in the report to maximize the opportunities for learning.

5.11.4 The IO will work with an Action Plan Lead (APL) designated by a member of the Divisional/Directorate Triumvirate to complete a comprehensive action plan that meets the recommendations from the report findings.
5.11.5 The IO is expected to conduct the investigation in line with the timescales set out in Appendix E of the SI Procedure.
5.11.6 It is recommended that all Root Cause Analysis (RCA) trained Investigating Officers complete a minimum of two serious or internal investigations each year in order to maintain their skill set.
5.11.7 The Investigating Officer Resource Pack is provided to the allocated IO for each investigation.
Divisional/Directorate Triumvirates

5.12.1 Divisional / Clinical Directors are accountable for the quality and safety of all services provided within their division/directorate. Each Divisional / Directorate / Clinical Director will ensure the principles and practice described in Section 1 of this policy are embedded within their Division/Directorate through clear communication with all staff and effective clinical governance arrangements.

5.12.2 The Divisional/Clinical Director will designate an action plan lead (APL) to work with the lead IO on the drafting of an action plan in response to the investigation. The APL will coordinate the delivery of the action plan and will act as the internal key point of contact for the purposes of monitoring, reporting and providing assurance evidence when actions are completed.

5.12.3 The APL is responsible on behalf of the Divisional/Directorate/Clinical Director for feeding back to all those involved in the incident and updating the Governance and Risk Coordinator that this has occurred.

Deputy Directors of Nursing / Associate Directors of Nursing / Heads of Nursing and Quality / Head of Midwifery / Heads of Service are responsible for the supervision of nursing/midwifery staff in their division through Lead Nurses, Matrons, Ward and Unit Nurse Managers. They are expected to use visible leadership support to ensure that all clinical and non-clinical incidents are escalated, reported and investigated on behalf of the Divisional/Directorate Clinical Director.
5.13.1 They will be the first point of contact with the patient safety team on patient safety matters. This will include:
Providing assurance evidence of rapid response reactions, i.e. measures taken against immediate threats to safety or serious issues that need fast tracking;
Contributing to Initial Management Review (IMR) / 3 day reports as appropriate;
Contributing to serious incident root cause analysis investigations;
Considering whether safeguarding thresholds have been met;
Ensuring all reporters of incidents receive an acknowledgement and are made aware of any actions arising from incidents.
5.13.2 Using specific findings and trend analysis from patient safety incidents they are responsible for:
Identifying all learning opportunities and widely publicising corrective actions required or taken, including changes in nursing and midwifery policy and practice;

Acting as the designated action plan lead (APL) where required by the Divisional / Directorate / Clinical Director to oversee and provide assurance evidence that action plans have been achieved within the agreed timeframe.

Associate Directors of Operations / Divisional Managers are expected to reinforce the principles and practice described in section 1.0 of this policy with their staff groups, supporting investigations as and when required.

Divisional / Directorate Governance and Risk Coordinators / Facilitators are responsible for ensuring that the incident reporting and investigation systems and controls in their area operate effectively and in accordance with Trust policy. This includes:
Monitoring all KPIs related to the investigation and closure of all incidents, including SIs.
Providing data and analysis of incidents using the Trust's incident reporting systems as required by divisional senior management teams and other staff groups.
In the event of a SI, supporting the Investigating Officer throughout the investigation process as required, including:
Ensuring robust governance systems are in place to monitor, record, analyse and report on:

Considering whether the incident may meet the threshold for a safeguarding referral, including neglect, willful neglect and acts of omission. Refer to safeguarding guidance and the Safeguarding Teams for further advice.

5.15.1 This includes providing reports on themes and trends, highlighting areas of potential concern, and correlating incident information with that from other sources such as complaints and PALs, claims, patient experience feedback and clinical audit, thereby identifying potential risks to the Division in the delivery of high quality and safe care. Where indicated lessons learnt should be shared across the divisions and sites.
Safeguarding team

5.16.1 The Associate Director of Safeguarding is responsible for ensuring the reporting framework for Safeguarding operates and supports the Incident Reporting Policy. All Safeguarding incidents must be reviewed by the Associate Director of Safeguarding or their delegated site leads and escalated in accordance with external Safeguarding Southend Essex and Thurrock procedures. If the alleged harm has occurred within the organisation or by the organisation this should include ensuring that any completed Safeguarding referral form has an associated incident form.

5.16.2 The Safeguarding Team maintain data in order to provide reports to relevant groups, internal and external, as required and takes part in any investigation where Safeguarding is believed to be a factor.
(Refer to relevant Safeguarding policies for further guidance)
Accountable Officer for Controlled Drugs

5.17.1 The site Accountable Officer will ensure that reports of any incident involving Controlled Drugs is made to the Managing Director of the Essex Area Team, Controlled Drugs Local Intelligence Network (CD LIN) and the police where appropriate.

Medication Safety Officer (MSO) Pharmacist (or nominated deputy) is responsible for managing and overseeing the medication safety strategy for the organisation including supporting medication incident reporting and investigation in the organisation and developing and leading on medication safety initiatives to reduce error incidents and harm.

Health and Safety Manager will review all incident reports relating to matters of health and safety supporting investigations as required. They will co-ordinate the analysis of data from health and safety related incidents and provide regular monitoring reports to the site Health and Safety Group.

5.19.1 They will also seek advice from responsible directors on the reporting of appropriate incidents in a timely manner to the Health and Safety Executive (HSE) as they occur and ensure learning from these incidents is recorded, disseminated and evidenced. (Refer to the Health and Safety Policy)
Local Counter Fraud Specialist

5.20.1 The Secretary of State Directions to NHS Bodies on Counter Fraud Measures (2004) require each NHS Body to appoint an LCFS. This officer's role is to ensure that all cases of actual or suspected fraud are notified to the Trust's Chief Finance Officer and NHS Counter Fraud Authority.

5.20.2 Any incident or suspicion of Fraud or Bribery should be reported to the Trust's LCFS. The LCFS will liaise with the regional Area Anti-Fraud Specialist and NHS Counter Fraud Authority and in conjunction with the Chief Finance Officer will decide who will conduct the investigation and when/if referral to the Police is required.
All Managers at all levels within the Trust are responsible for:
Encouraging a just culture within their service area.
Ensuring all staff encouraged to report incidents.
Ensuring incident reporting arrangements are implemented within their service areas.
Following an incident, take immediate action within the scope of their remit to prevent recurrence and/or eliminate or reduce any identified risks i.e. make the individual or environment safe.
Provide immediate and appropriate support to staff, patients and families following incidents, in line with the principles of Being Open and Duty of Candour, where required.

5.21.1 In the event of an SI or potential SI, they must notify internal stakeholders such as Executive Directors, Care Group Leadership Teams, the designated site lead for governance, Patient Safety Team as appropriate, following the flowchart at Appendix E of the Procedure for the Reporting and Management of Incidents and Serious Incidents Requiring Investigation.
Conduct local investigation into all reported incidents at the appropriate and proportionate level.
In conjunction with the Patient Safety Team, make arrangements to notify any other regulatory body of any incident as appropriate to their service area or function.

Conduct a risk assessment and notify their line manager of identified risks highlighted by an incident or near miss, where risks cannot be reduced to an acceptable level (please refer to the Risk Management Policy and Procedure for further guidance).

Complete and close incident forms within their service area, via the Trust Incident Reporting System, and/or nominate a staff member to do this on their behalf, ensuring that all mandatory sections are completed with appropriate information and evidence of appropriate investigation.
Adhere to the Trust's key performance measures for investigation and closure of incidents (20 day standard).
Use information from reported incidents, including analyses of themes and trends, to inform the undertaking and review of risk assessments for their
service areas.
Ensure an appropriate individual(s) within their service area is nominated to sign off incident forms in their absence.
Lessons learnt are shared at relevant Departmental and team meetings and through appropriate safety newsletters or bulletins.
Where appropriate lessons learnt will be shared across the Divisions / Directorates.
All staff
Report all incidents and near misses via the Trust's electronic Incident Management System.
Ensure the details of any incident are contemporaneously and objectively reported in the patient's clinical record.
Raise any concerns about situations that led to, or could lead to, an incident or a near miss with their line manager or the Patient Safety Team.
Actively participate in any subsequent incident investigation such as: providing a written account of the incident; attending multidisciplinary fact- finding and feedback meetings.
Attend a Coroner's Inquest on behalf of the Trust if called to do so.
Undertake training in the reporting of incidents and risk assessments.
Undertake additional training, as required, to ensure competence in relation to the Trusts electronic Incident Reporting System and root cause analysis.
5.22.1 The Trust will make available appropriate support to those staff involved in an incident, where this is required.
Procedure

The detail for reporting incidents and managing Incidents and Serious Incidents can be found in the Procedure for Reporting and Managing Incidents and Serious Incidents. For the purpose of this policy high level detail will be provided and a flowchart can be found at Appendix E for ease of reference.
Immediate response following an incident or near miss event:
The needs of patients and their family / carers must be made the first priority.

In all instances, the first priority of anyone involved in an incident is to ensure the needs of individuals affected are attended to, including any urgent clinical care that may reduce the harmful impact. The risk of recurrence should be considered immediately and actions taken to mitigate such a risk in advance of any investigation.

A safe environment must be re-established, all equipment or medication quarantined, labelled and isolated, and all relevant documentation copied and secured to preserve evidence to facilitate the investigation and learning. To maintain product liability, no piece of equipment should be returned to the manufacturer for repair/examination until the Trust has carried out all necessary tests on the equipment as suggested by the MHRA.
If required measurements, drawings or photographs of the location of the incident should be taken.
The incident should be reported via the incident reporting system.

The line manager should be informed so they are able to determine if there are any potential risks that need to be assessed, and can provide good oversight of any problems that require senior support. This may include considering whether staff are able to continue on their shift.

If there is a suggestion that a criminal offence has been committed, the Police must be contacted. Staff should be prepared to provide statements and line managers should provide support. The template for completing a written statement can be found on the intranet.

Consideration should be given as to whether the incident meets the threshold for a safeguarding referral, including neglect, willful neglect and acts of omission. Refer to safeguarding guidance and the Safeguarding Teams for further advice. In all incidences of a potential Safeguarding concern then an incident form must be raised ensuring that the category
is identified as Safeguarding.
Being Open and the Duty of Candour

6.3.1 There is a contractual and legislative responsibility for all healthcare organisations to be open and transparent with patients and their families when things go wrong with care delivery. This forms the basic principle of Being Open and Duty of Candour.
6.3.2 Further detail pertaining to Duty of Candour and Being Open can be found within the Being Open/Duty of Candour Policy.
Incident Review

6.4.1 All patient safety incidents are reviewed daily (Monday to Friday) by the Divisional / Directorate teams and the Patient Safety Team to quality assure the content, level of harm and identification of incidents in the correct location.

6.4.2 As part of this process if an incident is identified that potentially meets the criteria of a Serious Incident, then a request for an Initial Management Review will be generated for the Divisional / Directorate / Department Management teams to complete and return for further analysis at the Executive Review Group.
Local post-incident reporting – Initial Management Review (potential SIs)

6.5.1 The Divisional / Directorate management team will provide a completed Initial Management Review (IMR) where an incident is a potential SI in conjunction with the local manager for the service where the incident occurred.

6.5.2 This report should be completed as soon as possible after the incident, normally within 24 hours and submitted to the Patient Safety Team. Following quality assurance by the Patient Safety Team, the report will be scheduled for review at the next available Executive review Group.
Injurious Falls and Hospital Acquired Pressure Ulcers

6.6.1 The Harm Free Group oversee the review of bespoke root cause analysis investigation reports for injurious falls and pressure ulcers. All RCA's will be completed within 7 days and presented at this group.
6.6.2 Any pressure ulcers with lapses in care will be reviewed to establish whether they meet the threshold for a safeguarding referral.
Safeguarding incidents – children or adults at risk

6.7.1 Any incident involving child protection or an unexpected child death that occurred whilst the patient was under the direct care of the Trust and fits the definition of a Serious Incident will be declared as a Serious Incident following the normal SI processes.

6.7.2 An incident or an unexpected child death identified by Trust staff, but that did not take place whilst the child was directly or solely under the care of the Trust, will be considered as a possible Serious Incident. A multi-agency review will take place led by the Trust Named Professionals for Safeguarding Children and the Clinical Commissioning group Designated Nurse for Safeguarding Children.

6.7.3 This multiagency review will advise if the incident fits the National Framework SI criteria. This will then be reviewed by the Trust's Medical Director or Director of Nursing who will make the final decision as to whether the incident is declared as a Serious Incident.
6.7.4 The initial review by the Named and Designated professionals will also determine which of the organisations involved in the child's care will lead the investigation.

6.7.5 If the incident is declared as a Serious Incident, the lead organisation will appoint an Investigating Officer who will be responsible for coordinating the investigation and compiling the report.

6.7.6 The Serious Incident will be declared and entered on STEIS by the Trust even if it is not the lead organisation. It will then be transferred to the lead organisation by the Commissioner. If the Trust is not the lead organisation, the Trust will co-operate with the investigation providing any information about the child's contact with the Trust to the lead organisation. This will be led by the Trust's Named Professionals for Safeguarding Children.
Incidents involving the restraint of patients

6.8.1 All incidents where patients have been physically or chemically restrained must be reported and reviewed, and a decision made as whether the incident meets the threshold for further investigation. The Department of Health Document “Positive and Proactive Care: reducing the need for restrictive interventions” (2014) defines restrictive as:
Deliberate acts on the part of other person(s) that restrict an individual's movement, liberty and / or freedom to act independently in order to:
Take immediate control of a dangerous situation where there is a real possibility of harm to the person or other if no action is undertaken: and
End or reduce significantly the danger to the person or others; and
Contain or limit the persons freedom for no longer than is necessary

6.8.2 Chemical restraint is the use of medication which is prescribed and administered for the purpose of controlling or subduing violent behaviour, where it is not prescribed for the treatment of a formally identified physical or mental illness.
Healthcare Associated Infections (HCAI)
6.9.1 Some incidents involving HCAIs should be reported to the Commissioners
and NHS Midlands and East via the serious incident reporting process. The categories for reporting include:
Outbreaks of healthcare associated infection (this includes the presumed transmission within a hospital and causes significant morbidity, mortality and or impacts significantly on hospital activity).
Cases of Methicillin Resistant Staphyloccus Aureus bacteraemia attributed to the Trust
Infected healthcare workers (incidents which necessitate consideration of a look back exercise).
Breakdown of infection control procedures and or serious
decontamination failures with actual or potential for cross infection.

6.9.2 The Trust and Commissioners will manage the serious incident with advice and support from colleagues in the HPA; however the NHSE has an identified team to provide additional advice, support and guidance both in the reporting and management of ongoing infection incidents
Incidents of fraud or suspected fraud

6.10.1 In the event of fraudulent or suspected fraudulent activity, the Local Counter Fraud Specialist is to be notified immediately. Reference must be made to the Trust's Counter Fraud policy for guidance on how to report and manage this category of incident.
Incidents of violence and aggression

6.11.1 Any incident where physical contact was made with a member of staff in a violent or aggressive manner must be reported, including incidents where the clinical condition of a patient may be a factor.
Serious Incidents related to Clinical Research

6.12.1 All clinical research needs to be approved via the National Research Ethics Service NRES) and the site research and development department (R&D) before any NHS patients and staff can be approached to be involved in research.

6.12.2 If an incident occurs in relation to NHS patients or staff whereby harm has been caused or confidentiality has been breached or any other outcome which would constitute a serious incident, this should be reported in accordance with this policy and the incident should be reported to the relevant research body(ies).
Information Governance Incidents

6.13.1 This type of incident will typically breach one of the articles of the General Data Protection Regulation/UK Data Protection Legislation and/or the Common Law Duty of Confidentiality. This includes unlawful disclosure or misuse of confidential data, recording or sharing of inaccurate data, information security breaches and inappropriate invasion of people's privacy and personal data breaches which could lead to identity fraud or have other significant impact on individuals.
6.13.2 It applies irrespective of the media involved and includes both electronic media and paper records relating to staff and service users.

6.13.3 Serious incidents relating to breaches of confidentiality, data losses or breaches of IT security involving person identifiable data will be reviewed by the Information Governance Team and reported on the Data Security Protection Toolkit (DSPT) if they are to be reported to Information Commissioner's Office. Under the current regulations, the Trust has 72 hours of becoming aware of a serious information governance breach to inform the Information Commissioner's Office.
6.13.4 Serious incidents involving data losses and breaches in confidentiality must be detailed in the Trust's Annual Reports.
Healthcare Safety Investigation Branch – maternity incidents meeting criteria

6.14.1 The HSIB are responsible for carrying out maternity investigations as part of a national strategy to improve maternity safety. Where an incident meets the criteria of ‘Each Baby Counts' or is a maternal death within 42 days of birth the HSIB must be notified of the incident. This excludes suicide or homicide.
External Organisation Incident Alerts

6.15.1 NHS Care providers have a duty to alert other organisations to any incidents identified that could or have put a patients safety at risk or compromised their on-going care to enable continuous learning and promote patient safety.
6.15.2 Staff should report all incidents which are identified as occurring whilst the patient was under the care of an external organisation via the Trusts Incident Management System.
6.15.3 The Divisional / Directorate should determine whether completion of an External Incident Alert form is required and if so attach this to the Incident
Management System detailing the secure email address of the recipient. The Patient Safety Team should be advised to allow the alert to be securely sent to the appropriate organisation.

6.15.4 External Incident Alerts received by the Trust must be logged on the Trust Incident Management System. On completion the response section of the Alert must be completed by the Directorate and attached to the system. Where a failure of care is identified as a result of this investigation this may trigger additional investigation in accordance with the policy.
6.15.5 Once approved, the response will be forwarded on via the secure email account.
General Incident closure
6.16.1 The criteria for judging an incident to be ‘closed' will be proportionate. Irrespective of the level of harm and including near miss events, all incident reports should include details of:
All actions taken;
Investigation findings;
Lessons learned;
Any further action required.
Internal Investigation/Serious Incident closure

6.17.1 Where the incident is judged as requiring an Internal Investigation or a serious incident requiring comprehensive investigation, then specific actions must be completed within the agreed timescales prior to the incident being closed. This will provide the Commissioners with sufficient assurance of robust clinical governance practice in place. Such actions include:
An appropriate investigation has been completed that identifies findings, based on root causes and recommendations within mandated timescales;
A satisfactory action plan with actions points to address each root cause recommendation(s) and with a named lead and timescale for implementation normally within 100 working days;
Evidence of lessons learned, including partners or stakeholders with whom the learning has been shared.
Notification to internal and external stakeholders, agencies and regulatory bodies

7.1.1  Upon receipt of a completed incident report, the Patient Safety Team will ensure the appropriate internal and external stakeholders, agencies and regulatory bodies are informed as appropriate and within stipulated timescales.
Reporting RIDDOR incidents to the Health and Safety Executive (HSE) is the responsibility of the Health and Safety Team, following review of the incident, and following approval by a Site Director.
For all injurious patient falls the RIDDOR Guidance will be discussed at the Harm Free Group and will then be escalated to DRG for Director Approval of RIDDOR declaration.

All confirmed serious incidents must be notified to the relevant bodies without delay and within two working days. It is the role of the Patient Safety team to ensure that incidents and serious incidents are reported via the National Reporting and Learning System (NRLS) and so the Care Quality Commission (CQC) as required by the Health and Social Care Act 2012, NHSI as the Trust's licensing authority, and to the Trust's commissioners via the Strategic Executive Information System (STEIS) within the required
timescales.
Never Events
7.2.1  In the case of a confirmed Never Event, all reporting documentation must clearly indicate ‘Never Event' throughout.
The patient, family and/or carer must be informed as part of meeting the Duty of Candour that the incident is a potential Never Event.

If a Never Event is identified following incident review by the Patient Safety Team, the designated site lead for governance (or nominated deputy) will inform the Executive Directors, Care Group leadership teams and Chief Executive.
The Never Event will be reported to the Clinical Commissioning Group/Acute Commissioning Team within one working day.
The Never Event will be reported through to NHSI and the Care Quality Commission once the Never Event has been confirmed.
Please refer to the Never Event management and escalation chart – appendix F.
Grading of incidents

8.1.1 All incidents and near misses will be subject to a level of investigation proportionate to their severity. The appropriate manager will confirm the level of actual harm caused to patient/relative/staff member.
8.1.2 If the incident has not caused harm to either a person or the organisation, then this will be considered to be a no harm incident.
8.1.3 A near miss is any event that occurred, which was not anticipated or planned, which did not actually lead to harm, loss or damage, but under different circumstances could have done.
8.1.4 The Patient Safety Team will support the consistent grading of harm on a daily basis.
Local responsibility for investigations

8.2.1 Where an incident is identified as causing no harm to minor harm, a senior member of staff in charge of the area where the incident occurred, is responsible for ensuring an appropriate member of staff investigates the incident. Findings and learning from local incidents will then be recorded in the appropriate field on the Electronic Incident Reporting System.
8.2.2 The local manager is responsible for ensuring all changes are made and learning shared with staff in response to incidents to reduce the risk of recurrence.
Bespoke investigations

8.3.1 For certain incidents that occur, specific investigations must be undertaken to provide the Trust and the Commissioners that there is sufficient rigor in the investigation process. These include:
Hospital acquired pressure ulcers;
Patient falls resulting in harm;
Healthcare associated infections;
Hospital acquired venous thrombus emboli;
Abuse of vulnerable individuals.

8.3.2 The Patient Safety Team will ensure that the appropriate investigation tools and bespoke report templates are used so that there is consistency in the reporting of such incidents, that support shared learning and the improvement of clinical practice.
8.3.3 Pressure ulcers and injurious falls will be discussed and peer reviewed at Harm Free Group or equivalent. VTE RCAs will be presented at ERG for a decision on declaration.
Risk summit and external reviews

8.4.1 A risk summit may be called where themes and trends have been identified through ERG or IRP. The panel will be chaired by either the Chief Nurse or Chief Medical Director or Care Group Leadership Team with appropriate representation from the Divisional / Directorate teams. The action plans formulated from a Risk Summit will be monitored at the Patient Safety and Quality Group.
8.4.2 Where a cluster of incidents or serious incidents has occurred within a specialty, the members of the risk summit will consider commissioning an external review of the service.
Root cause analysis (RCA) investigation report

9.1.1 For internal and serious incidents, the lead investigating officer is responsible for completing a draft report using the appropriate Trust template, which will be provided by the Patient Safety Team.

9.1.2 The draft report will be based on the information gleaned from statements from staff and others and analysis using relevant tools available within the IO pack provided by the Patient Safety Team and designed to identify care and service delivery problems and contributory factors. This analysis should take account of human factors involved at the time of the incident.
All incidents not identified as Serious Incidents
9.2.1  The Division / Directorate / Department is expected to investigate and close Incident Reports within 20 days, unless it has been declared an Internal or Serious Incident.
Internal Investigations

9.3.1 All Internal Investigations must have an internal investigation report completed. This must be submitted to the Patient Safety Team within 7 working days of the incident being declared at ERG as requiring an internal investigation.

9.3.2 The report must also include recommendations for immediate action to maintain patient safety. These will be audited by the Divisional / Directorate Governance Facilitators / Coordinators and Patient Safety Team for evidence of action and learning.
Serious Incidents

9.4.1 A full Root Cause Analysis Investigation Report must be submitted to the Patient Safety Team within 40 working days (8 weeks) for quality assurance and review, following approval within the Division / Directorate (with a signed off checklist by a member of the triumvirate). It is the responsibility of the Divisional / Directorate Governance lead in conjunction with the Investigating Officer to ensure an action plan is developed alongside the report and submitted for simultaneous review.

9.4.2 Following quality assurance and any further amendments requested, the final report must have been approved first vis the Investigation Review Panel and subsequently by the Executive Review Group in readiness for submission to the Commissioners within 60 working days (12 weeks) from the incident being declared as a Serious Incident and reported on STEIS.
(Refer to the process chart in Appendix E).
9.4.2  Maternity Serious Incident Investigation Report

All serious incident reports generated in response to concerns with care provided within the Maternity Service will be shared in full with Board members via the Maternity Assurance Committee (MAC). These reports will be shared in advance of each meeting.
In addition a monthly report summarising the concerns and findings will be provided to the MAC and to the LMNS.
Action plans

9.5.1 All action plans, whether arising from an Internal Incident or Serious Incident, are the responsibility of the area where the incident occurred to implement and monitor, coordinated by the Action Plan Lead.
9.5.2 All actions plans must be available with evidence for closure within 100 working days (20 weeks) from the incident being declared as an SI and reported on STEIS.
9.5.3 The requirement is that action plans will be closed with all evidence embedded by 120 working days.
9.5.4 Action Plans for Injurious Falls and Hospital Acquired Pressure ulcers will be discussed and evidence checked at the relevant Harm Free Group.
Tracking and assuring actions

9.6.1 Whilst implementation of the actions following serious incident investigations lies at a divisional level, it is the responsibility of the Patient Safety Team to provide a tracking system for all serious incident action plans.

9.6.2 Divisions / directorates / departments will be expected to provide regular updates on their achievement against any serious incident action plans, highlighting where actions are overdue or non-achievement of deadlines is anticipated, providing assurance evidence when actions are reported as ‘complete'.
(Refer to MSEPO – 19015 Procedure for the reporting and management of incidents and serious incidents for further details)
Learning lessons

10.1.1 One of the principal aims of the serious incident reporting and learning process is to reduce the risk of recurrence. The timely and appropriate dissemination of learning following an SI or internal investigation is core to achieving this and to ensure that these lessons are embedded in practice.
10.1.2 For organisational learning some lessons learnt will be shared through site and group forums and communications.
Definition of learning in the context of patient safety
10.2.1 Learning from a patient safety incident should be a collaborative and reflective process that draws on experience, knowledge and evidence from a variety of sources.
Organisational learning can be demonstrated by sustainable changes and improvements in process, policy, systems and procedures relating to patient safety.
Individual learning can be demonstrated by sustainable changes and improvements in behaviour, beliefs, and attitudes and knowledge of workers at the front line of service delivery.
Analysis of incident data

10.3.1 The Incident Management System enables data from reported incidents to be analysed for themes, trends or patterns, and such information will be organised in the preparation of performance and assurance reports to the Trust Board, its sub-committees and all other patient safety related committees and groups, as required Divisional / Directorate Governance facilitators / coordinators have direct access to the Electronic Incident Reporting Management System and can either produce their own reports or request them through the Patient Safety Team as part of their responsibilities.
10.3.2 A monthly serious incident report will be provided to each Patient Safety and Quality Group meeting and to each Quality Governance Committee.
Patients and/or family/carers

11.1.1 The responsibility to communicate with patients and/or families and carers rests with the Division / Directorate with primary responsibility for completing incident investigation. (Refer to the Trust's Being Open and Duty of Candour Policy for further details)
Staff involved in incidents

11.2.1 The Trust recognises that reporting and being involved in an incident can be very distressing. Therefore, the relevant manager should always ensure that sufficient support has been provided to staff involved, seeking advice and guidance from the Trust's Occupational Health Department where required.

11.2.2 The culture of ‘open and just' is reinforced and upheld strongly within the Trust; therefore, any incident is reviewed by the Patient Safety Team to ensure that all incidents are reviewed and that further information is requested where there is a lack of information relating to systems failure.
Hotline arrangements

11.3.1 In the case of an incident that has affected a large number of individuals who may need either to be contacted by, or who may need to contact the Trust, a dedicated hotline will be set up that is coordinated by the Communications Department. The Communications Department will publish information to staff, patients and the public by the appropriate route. When setting up such arrangements, the Communications Department will give consideration to the following:
Management responsibility;
Media management;
Phone lines;
Internet and Intranet information;
Staffing;
Capacity to manage calls over time;
Documentation;
Record keeping;
IT/email and postal arrangements.
Claims for compensation following incidents relating to loss of
patient property
Staff or patients who have incurred financial loss as a result of theft or damage to clothing or belongings while on Trust premises may wish to claim for the loss.

The Trust will not accept responsibility for patients' items not handed in for safe-keeping. There may be circumstances however where an ex-gratia payment to cover minor damages to clothing or belongings during an incident may be appropriate. Please refer to the relevant site policy for managing patient valuables.

It is the duty of all Trust staff to share any concerns about issues that affect staff or patient safety, or other significant issue, either directly with their line manager or through Trust specialist advisors. Staff should also feel free to raise concerns without fear of recrimination through the Trust's Speak Up policy, which is available on the Trust's intranet site.
Contact details of the Trust's Freedom to Speak up Guardian(s) are available via on the Intranet.

All staff must receive relevant guidance and training to help them identify, report and investigate incidents appropriate to their role. Healthcare provider organisations are required to include the reporting and management of serious incidents as part of staff induction and ongoing training.
The Patient Safety Team are available to provide bespoke training on all aspects of incident and serious incident reporting, investigation, action planning and management.

Investigating Officers for Serious Incidents must have completed the RCA training provided by the Patient Safety Team. The staff completing the full RCA training must be of a senior position within the organisation - Consultants, Heads of Nursing or Midwifery/Departments, Service Unit Managers, Matrons/Lead Nurses, Specialist nurses and Governance and Risk Facilitators / Coordinators.
It is recommended that all Root Cause Analysis (RCA) trained Investigating Officers complete a minimum of two Serious or Internal investigations each year in order to maintain their skill set.
Bespoke training for hospital acquired pressure ulcers and falls investigation will be provided to Senior Sisters/Charge Nurses and Ward Sisters and Charge Nurses.

The Trust will monitor compliance with this policy through review and monitoring of key performance indicators at agreed divisional / directorate governance meetings and Risk and Compliance Group or equivalent meeting. The key performance indicators will include the following as a minimum:
Meeting Duty of Candour requirements;
Submission of the  hour report to the Commissioners;
Number of serious incident investigations breaching  days / agreed
extensions;
Number of serious incident action plans overdue for closure.
